operational.availability: The proportion of time the system is functional and accessible (often measured in 'nines').
operational.reliability: The ability of the system to perform its intended functions under stated conditions for a specified period.
operational.performance_efficiency: The system's responsiveness and throughput relative to the resources consumed (CPU, memory, bandwidth).
operational.scalability: The ability to handle increasing workloads by adding resources (Vertical/Scale-up or Horizontal/Scale-out).
operational.security: The degree to which the system protects information and data from unauthorized access or modification.
operational.robustness: The ability of a system to maintain its function even when faced with invalid inputs or stressful environmental conditions.
operational.resilience: The ability of a system to recover quickly from failures or 'bounce back' after a disruption.
operational.observability: The degree to which the internal state of the system can be inferred from its external outputs (logs, metrics, traces).

structural.maintainability: The ease with which a system can be modified to correct defects, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.
structural.testability: The degree to which the system supports testing to verify its requirements and logic.
structural.modularity: The extent to which a system's components may be separated and recombined.
structural.extensibility: The ability to add new functionality to a system without changing its existing architecture.
structural.reusability: The degree to which assets (code, components) can be used in more than one software system.
structural.readability: The ease with which a human developer can understand the source code and logic flow.

environmental.portability: The ease with which a system can be transferred from one hardware or software environment to another.
environmental.interoperability: The ability of two or more systems or components to exchange and use information.
environmental.deployability: The ease and speed with which a system can be moved from a development state into production.
environmental.compliance: The degree to which the system adheres to laws, regulations, and industry standards.

user_centric.usability: The ease of use and learnability of the system for its intended users.
user_centric.accessibility: The degree to which a system is usable by people with the widest range of capabilities.
